questions.text: A five-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician to evaluate recurrent ear infections and sinusitis. The parent states, “He always seems to be sick with something. Every week, he is coughing or tugging on his ear. His nose runs constantly.” The patient was born full-term without complications during pregnancy or delivery. He has no other medical problems and does not take any medications daily. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates clear nasal secretions and hyperemia of the nasal mucosa bilaterally. After appropriate work-up and first-line medication trials, a nasal mucosa biopsy is performed and sent for transmission electron microscopy. Upon analysis of the specimen, the patient is found to have an absence of dynein arms on microtubule assemblies. Which of the following cardiac anomalies is most likely to be present given this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Apex of the heart located in the right chest
Displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle
Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular cardiac septum

questions.solution:
This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia (sometimes known as Karatagener syndrome), which arises due to defective dynein arms of the microtubule, resulting in impaired ciliary function. Ciliary dysfunction manifests as recurrent sinopulmonary infections, infertility (secondary to immotile sperm or immotile fallopian cilia), and bronchiectasis. This condition is highly associated with situs inversus, an embryological folding defect in which the thoracic and abdominal viscera are transposed across the midline (including the heart, a phenomenon termed dextrocardia).  

Patients with dextrocardia (whether in isolation or in association with situs inversus) will often have a palpable apex heartbeat over the right chest. On screening electrocardiogram, patients will have evidence of right axis deviation, inversion of all complexes in lead I, upright p waves in AVL, and an absent R wave progression in the anterior leads. A chest x-ray will demonstrate the apex of the heart in the right chest.  

It should be noted that when the condition occurs in isolation, dextrocardia is often associated with additional, more severe cardiac anomalies as compared to situs inversus, which is typically benign and often diagnosed incidentally.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Apex of the heart located in the right chest :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle :
Incorrect: Ebstein anomaly is caused by in utero exposure to lithium. This condition is also associated with tricuspid regurgitation and isolated right heart failure. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular cardiac septum :
Incorrect: This answer describes Tetralogy of Fallot, the most common cause of early childhood cyanosis. This condition more commonly presents with tet-spells–episodes of cyanosis on exertion resulting from right to left shunting. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Transpositioned aorta and pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: Transposition of the great vessels is a rare congenital cardiac defect that results in death within the first few months of life if untreated. It is not associated with ciliary dysfunction or upper respiratory infections. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Tricuspid atresia :
Incorrect: Tricuspid atresia is the congenital absence of a tricuspid valve, with a subsequently hypoplastic right ventricle. This condition requires both a ventricular septal and atrial septal defect for survival. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of hypertension. The patient was seen in the emergency department last week for a laceration repair, and her systolic blood pressure was noted to be over 200 mmHg. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 225/102 mmHg in the right upper extremity and 210/97 in the left upper extremity. The patient has a 2/6 systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. The patient’s lower extremities have scant hair bilaterally, and a brachiofemoral pulse delay is noted bilaterally. A portion of the patient’s chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has uncontrolled hypertension, which is the most common presentation for adult patients with undiagnosed coarctation of the aorta. Clues to this diagnosis include an systolic ejection murmur (indicative of a bicuspid aortic valve), brachiofemoral pulse delay, and rib notching noted in the chest radiograph above.  

Coarctation of the aorta is an overall common congenital anomaly, accounting for approximately 6-8% of all congenital heart disease. This anatomic defect refers to a discrete narrowing of the descending aorta at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, just distal to the left subclavian artery. The degree of defect varies amongst individuals. The condition has a high association with Turner syndrome and a bicuspid aortic valve.   

Due to the stenosis, patients develop hypertension in the upper extremities, diminished blood pressure in the lower extremities, and brachiofemoral pulse delay. In the thorax, notching of the posterior one-third of the third to eighth ribs occurs due to erosion caused by the formation of large collaterals in the intercostal arteries.  

Option Analysis

✅ Coarctation of the aorta :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Peripheral vascular disease :
Incorrect: Peripheral vascular disease can result in diminished or absent hair on the lower extremities. However, this condition would not account for the rib notching noted on the patient’s radiograph.   
❌ Abdominal aortic aneurysm :
Incorrect: An abdominal aortic aneurysm more commonly presents in patients with a long history of smoking and atherosclerotic disease. This diagnosis would not explain the rib notching noted on the patient’s radiograph. 
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy more commonly presents with signs of congestive heart failure, such as lower extremity edema, shortness of breath, and an S3 heart sound. This patient’s heart sound indicates a possible bicuspid aortic valve.
❌ Subclavian artery stenosis :
Incorrect: Subclavian steal syndrome refers to a phenomenon that occurs with severe stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the ipsilateral vertebral artery. It can manifest with exercise-induced ischemia of the affected limb.

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn male is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit for breathing difficulty. The patient was born at 39 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery at home, and this is his first medical evaluation. The mother is a 26-year-old woman who had minimal prenatal care. She reports that he “was fine” after birth, but after the first few days, she noted a constant bluish color of his lips. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 84% on room air. Physical exam shows low-set ears and bulbous nasal tip. Cardiac auscultation reveals a loud, single second heart sound and bounding peripheral pulses. Chest radiograph shows pulmonary congestion with increased pulmonary markings and decreased soft-tissue attenuation in the right anterior mediastinum. Which of the following cardiac defects is most likely to be seen with further analysis of this patient?
questions.solution:
This infant presenting with progressive cyanosis, absent thymus tissue (decreased soft-tissue attenuation in the right anterior mediastinum) and increased pulmonary markings on chest radiograph as well as characteristic facial appearance (low-set ears and bulbous nasal tip) most likely has DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion) with concomitant persistent truncus arteriosus.   

During the early stages of embryological heart development, the great vessels originate from a single truncus arteriosus (single arterial root). Persistent truncus arteriosus occurs when the single trunk fails to divide into the aorta and pulmonary trunk due to a defect in the aorticopulmonary septum formation. This is often accompanied by a single truncal valve and ventricular septal defect.  

Immediately after birth, the pulmonary vascular resistance is initially high, which causes relatively little left-to-right shunt through the single trunk. This allows a relatively normal amount of blood flow into the pulmonary circulation. However, as the pulmonary vascular resistance drops, the left-to-right shunting increases, leading to pulmonary overload, cyanosis, and heart failure.    

Cardiovascular findings include single second heart sound, ejection click at the apex or left sternal border, bounding peripheral pulses, and in patients with truncal valve regurgitation, a diastolic murmur may be heard along the left sternal border. On chest radiograph, cardiac enlargement, increased pulmonary markings and congestion are expected. The diagnosis is made by echocardiography and treatment includes medications for stabilization followed by surgical repair.

 



Option Analysis

❌ D-transposition of the great vessels:
Incorrect: D-transposition of the great vessels is another cause of early cyanosis and usually presents in the first days of life, depending on the associated cardiac defects (e.g., VSD, PDA). The chest radiograph of D-transposition of the great vessels will likely show an “egg on a string” appearance. However, the typical facial characteristics and the chest radiograph findings seen in this patient are consistent with the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion). DiGeorge syndrome is associated with Tetralogy of Fallot and persistent truncus arteriosus, not D-transposition of the great vessels.   
❌ Tricuspid atresia:
Incorrect: Tricuspid atresia often presents in the first days of life, depending on the presence of a ventricular septal defect. On physical examination, a single second heart sound (S2) can also be heard; however, the presence of bounding pulses and the chest radiograph findings in this case favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Tetralogy of Fallot:
Incorrect: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is also characterized by early cyanosis. The presentation is variable and depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. The typical facial characteristics and the chest radiograph findings seen in this patient are consistent with the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion). On physical examination, a single second heart sound (S2) is also heard; however, bounding pulses are characteristics of persistent truncus arteriosus. Moreover, TOF chest radiographs typically reveal a “boot-shaped” heart and decreased pulmonary markings, as the right ventricular outflow obstruction leads to decreased pulmonary flow.   
✅ Persistent truncus arteriosus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR):
Incorrect: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) is another cause of early cyanosis in which the four pulmonary veins fail to make their normal connection to the left atrium and instead drain into the right atrium. On physical examination, fixed splitting of the second heart sound occurs (S2) due to right ventricular overload, as well as a systolic ejection murmur due to increased volume across the pulmonary valve. On chest radiograph, the classic “snowman” appearance can sometimes be seen. The typical facial characteristics and the chest radiograph findings seen in this patient are consistent with the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion); DiGeorge syndrome is associated with Tetralogy of Fallot and persistent truncus arteriosus, not TAPVR.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance. He reports having difficulty keeping up with his friends while playing soccer. The patient recently immigrated to the United States. He previously had limited access to medical care. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a heart murmur can be auscultated at the left lower sternal border. No cyanosis of the skin or mucosal membranes is observed. Cardiac catheterization is performed and yields the results shown below.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation of these findings?

choices.text: Obstruction of blood flow across a cardiac valve
Impaired oxygen exchange in the lungs

questions.solution:
This patient with exercise intolerance and a heart murmur at the left lower sternal border (LLSB), together with cardiac catheterization showing an increase in oxygenation in the right ventricle, most likely has a ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common type of acyanotic congenital heart disease. The condition can cause fatigue, shortness of breath, exercise intolerance, and failure to thrive. VSDs are a type of left-to-right shunt, wherein oxygenated blood in the left heart passes through the defect and enters the right heart. Patients are acyanotic since deoxygenated blood from the right heart is unable to enter the systemic circulation. Other causes of left-to-right shunts include atrial septal defect, patent foramen ovale, and patent ductus arteriosus.  

In contrast, in a right-to-left shunt, deoxygenated blood from the right heart passes through a defect and enters the left heart. The deoxygenated blood subsequently enters the systemic circulation, resulting in cyanosis. Causes of right-to-left shunts include Tetralogy of Fallot and Eisenmenger syndrome, among others. 

Option Analysis

❌ Obstruction of blood flow across a cardiac valve :
Incorrect: Conditions such as mitral or atrial stenosis can result in impaired blood flow across the affected valves. Patients can present with dyspnea and easy fatigability. However, a valvular disorder would not account for the elevated oxygen saturation in the right ventricle and pulmonary artery. 
❌ Impaired oxygen exchange in the lungs :
Incorrect: Conditions ranging from pulmonary hypoplasia to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease can impair gas exchange in the lungs, which results in oxygen-poor blood returning to the left heart. In contrast, the blood in this patient’s left heart is well oxygenated. 
❌ Reversal of long-standing left-to-right shunt :
Incorrect: The reversal of a long-standing left-to-right shunt is termed Eisenmenger syndrome. Since deoxygenated blood is now able to enter the left heart and eventually the systemic circulation, patients with this condition present with cyanosis. In contrast, the patient in this vignette does not have cyanosis. 
❌ Right-to-left shunting of blood :
Incorrect: Right-to-left shunting allows deoxygenated blood in the right heart to enter to the left heart and subsequently the systemic circulation. This type of shunt would result in cyanosis and reduced oxygen saturation in the left heart. In contrast, this patient is acyanotic and has normal oxygen saturation levels in the left heart. 
✅ Left-to-right shunting of blood :
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for fatigue and leg pain that began around four months ago. The pain worsens with physical activity and improves with rest. She has no notable past medical history, aside from an episode of pharyngitis when she was 12 years old, which self-resolved. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and respirations are 20/min. Upper extremity blood pressure is 135/82 mmHg, and lower extremity blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows delay in the femoral pulse compared with the brachial pulse. No signs of cyanosis are observed. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Anterosuperior displacement of the interventricular septum
Incomplete closure of the mitral valve during systole
Fusion of the aortic valve leaflets

questions.solution:
This patient with fatigue, claudication, brachiofemoral delay and hypotension in lower extremities most likely has coarctation of aorta (CoA). CoA occurs when there is a specific point of narrowing of the lumen of the aorta, and it can be divided into two types: preductal and postductal.  

The preductal type (also termed the infantile type) presents early in life and is associated with a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). In this type, aortic narrowing occurs before the ductus arteriosus. Blood pressure is elevated in the aorta before the narrowing and reduced after the narrowing. As a result, deoxygenated blood is shunted from the pulmonary artery, through the ductus arteriosus, into the aorta distal to the narrowing. Deoxygenated blood can travel to the lower extremities and result in differential cyanosis, which is when the lower extremities are cyanotic, but the upper extremities are not.  

The postductal type (also termed the adult type) is not associated with a PDA. Narrowing occurs after the ductus arteriosus/ligamentum arteriosum. No shunting or differential cyanosis is present. However, blood pressure will still be elevated proximal to the narrowing and reduced distal to the narrowing. Of note, the patient in this vignette has the postductal type.  

Both types can cause upper extremity hypertension. In addition, if too little blood reaches the legs, patients can develop claudication that is exacerbated by exercise, as seen in this patient.

Option Analysis

❌ Anterosuperior displacement of the interventricular septum :
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The condition instead causes cyanosis that is triggered by crying or exercise. Moreover, it would not account for the blood pressure difference between the patient’s upper and lower extremities. 
❌ Incomplete closure of the mitral valve during systole :
Incorrect: This pathophysiology results in mitral regurgitation, which causes a systolic murmur loudest over the cardiac apex that radiates to the axilla. Rheumatic heart disease secondary to Streptococcus pyogenes infection can result in mitral regurgitation. However, it would be atypical for mitral regurgitation to present with upper extremity hypertension or lower extremity claudication.  
❌ Fusion of the aortic valve leaflets :
Incorrect: Fusion of the aortic valve leaflets would result in a bicuspid aortic valve, which predisposes patients to aortic stenosis. Since blood now has a harder time leaving the left heart, patients can develop fatigue and exercise intolerance. However, aortic stenosis would not cause hypertension only in the upper extremities. 
✅ Postductal narrowing of the aorta :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Preductal narrowing of the aorta :
Incorrect: This answer describes preductal coarctation of the aorta, which is associated with a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Since there is low blood pressure in the aorta distal to narrowing, right-to-left shunting can occur. Blood from the pulmonary artery can pass through the PDA and travel to the lower extremities. As a result, patients can develop lower extremity cyanosis. In contrast, no cyanosis is observed in this patient.

questions.text: An 18-year-old young man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of exertional shortness of breath. It worsens with exercise and improves with rest. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which he uses an albuterol inhaler occasionally. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 115/74 mmHg, and pulse is 67/min. Physical exam is notable for a systolic murmur most prominent at the left upper sternal border, as well as fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Incomplete fusion of the septum primum with endocardial cushions
Incomplete fusion of the septum primum with septum secundum
Impaired growth of the septum secundum
Impaired development of the membranous interventricular septum

questions.solution:
This patient with exertional dyspnea and examination findings of a systolic murmur that is most prominent at the left upper sternal border as well as fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound most likely has an atrial septal defect (ASD). Although most patients are asymptomatic, some can exhibit poor weight gain and exercise intolerance.  

ASDs can be subdivided into ostium secundum defects and ostium primum defects. Ostium secundum defects occur due to impaired growth of the septum secundum. This type is more common and is usually an isolated finding. In contrast, ostium primum defects occur due to incomplete fusion of the septum primum with the endocardial cushion. This type is uncommon and is associated with conditions such as trisomy 21.  

Option Analysis

❌ Incomplete fusion of the septum primum with endocardial cushions :
Incorrect: This patient has a fixed-split S2 heart sound, which is suggestive of an atrial septal defect. Ostium primum defects, wherein there is incomplete fusion of the septum primum with the endocardial cushions, can result in an ASD. However, ASDs are more frequently due to ostium secundum defects. 
❌ Incomplete fusion of the septum primum with septum secundum :
Incorrect: A patent foramen ovale (PFO) results from the incomplete fusion of the ostium primum and secundum. The condition is mostly asymptomatic. Patients may have a faint systolic murmur on auscultation. However, fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound would be an atypical presentation of PFO. 
✅ Impaired growth of the septum secundum :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Calcification of the aortic valve :
Incorrect: Calcification of the aortic valve can sometimes lead to aortic stenosis (AS). Because the left ventricle has to eject blood against greater resistance, patients with AS may develop paradoxical splitting, wherein the A2 sound occurs after the P2 sound. However, the condition would not cause fixed-splitting. In addition, the systolic murmur would be more prominent in the right second intercostal space. 
❌ Impaired development of the membranous interventricular septum :
Incorrect: This answer describes a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Wide-splitting of the S2 heart sound may be heard in patients with VSD because blood from the left ventricle can pass through the defect, enter the right ventricle, increase right ventricular volume, and prolong systole. However, VSD would not cause fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old male newborn is being evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit for progressive cyanosis, breathing difficulty and poor feeding. He was born to a 22-year-old mother who received no prenatal care. Temperature is 37.0° C (98.6° F), pulse is 160/min, blood pressure is 87/55 mm Hg, and respiration rate is 55/min. On physical examination, no craniofacial deformities are seen. Central cyanosis is present, and cardiac auscultation reveals fixed splitting of the second heart sound (S2) over the left upper sternal border. Chest radiograph is obtained and shown below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia    
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This newborn infant presents with progressive cyanosis, breathing difficulty and poor feeding, as well as a classic chest radiograph showing a “snowman sign.” He most likely has total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR).  

TAPVR is cyanotic heart disease of the newborn in which all four pulmonary veins fail to make their normal connection to the left atrium and instead drain into the systemic venous circulation. The clinical manifestations vary and mainly depend upon the presence and degree of pulmonary venous obstruction and interatrial communication. For the condition to be compatible with life, there is a need for a right to left shunt such as ASD or PDA. Without treatment, the survival rate is poor, with a mortality rate of 80% by 1 year of age.  

This classic chest radiograph shows “snowman sign” (figure of 8) due to dilation of the superior vena cava, pulmonary vein, and brachiocephalic artery which forms the snowman's “head,” while the dilated right atrium forms the snowman's “body.”  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia    

On physical examination, a fixed split second heart sound (S2) is heard due to right ventricular overload, which delays the pulmonary valve closure. Other physical findings include hepatomegaly (due to right-sided failure), tachypnea, and cyanosis. Diagnosis is generally made by echocardiography, and initial medical management is focused on stabilization of the patients prior to surgical correction.  

Option Analysis

❌ D-transposition of the great vessels:
Incorrect: D-transposition of the great vessels (D-TGA) is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn in which the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. This dual circulation is incompatible with life unless there is communication between the two parallel circuits, such as a ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD) or patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). D-TGA often presents with a classic chest radiograph revealing an “egg on a string” appearance rather than the “snowman sign” seen in this patient. 
❌ Persistent truncus arteriosus:
Incorrect: Persistent truncus arteriosus (TA) is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn, in which there is a failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form, resulting in a common arterial trunk. Chest radiography in TA typically shows cardiac enlargement and increased pulmonary vascular markings, rather than the “snowman sign” seen in this patient. Other findings of TA include prominent second heart sounds, ejection clink, and bounding pulses. TA is also often associated with DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion), and other features would be expected.
✅ Total anomalous pulmonary venous return:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tetralogy of Fallot:
Incorrect: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn, and it includes the following features: pulmonary infundibular stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect. The classic chest radiograph of a patient with TOF depicts a "boot-shaped" heart with an upturned apex rather than the “snowman sign” seen in this patient. Also, the murmur of TOF is typically a harsh systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur. TOF is often associated with DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion), and other craniofacial features would be expected.
❌ Tricuspid atresia:
Incorrect: Tricuspid atresia is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn, and it is characterized by congenital agenesis or absence of the tricuspid valve. On chest radiograph, the smooth convexity of the right heart border is absent, and the right heart border does not cross beyond the spine. On auscultation, a single second heart sound (S2) is heard, rather than fixed splitting.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room for evaluation of left-arm weakness that began three-hours ago. Two-days ago, the patient returned from an overseas conference. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 143/87 mmHg. Physical examination reveals motor strength of 3/5 in the left upper and lower extremities and 5/5 in the right upper and lower extremities. Cardiac examination reveals a fixed-split S2 heart sound. Ultrasound of the lower extremities shows a blood clot in the right popliteal vein. Which of the following findings will most likely be present in this patient?

choices.text: Presence of bruit on carotid auscultation
Increased oxygen saturation in the right atrium

questions.solution:
This patient recently took a long flight after which he developed a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his popliteal vein. In addition, he most likely has an atrial septal defect (ASD), given examination finding of a fixed split S2 heart sound. The combination of these two factors means that the clot likely travelled to the right atrium and passed through the defect into the arterial circulation, ending up in cerebral vasculature, causing a stroke. This phenomenon is termed paradoxical embolism, which is a known complication of ASD.  

ASD is an acyanotic congenital heart defect that arises from impaired growth or excess resorption of the atrial septum. Most patients are asymptomatic. However, some can exhibit poor weight gain or exercise intolerance. It can cause a systolic ejection murmur loudest over the left upper sternal border. In addition, patients can have fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound, which occurs due to ASD equalizing the effect that inspiration and expiration has on right and left ventricular output. Cardiac catheterization will show elevated oxygen saturation in the right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary artery. As mentioned above, ASDs can contribute to the development of paradoxical emboli.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Weakened bilateral femoral pulses :
Incorrect: Coarctation of the aorta can reduce blood flow to the lower extremity, resulting in weakened femoral pulses. In addition, the condition can cause hypertension and cerebral aneurysms. However, coarctation of the aorta would cause a continuous murmur and not a fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound. 
❌ Elevated activated partial thromboplastin time :
Incorrect: This finding can be observed in patients with antiphospholipid syndrome (APLS). APLS can potentially explain the patient’s DVT. However, it would neither explain the heart murmur nor how an embolus from the popliteal vein ended up getting lodged in the cerebral vasculature, rather than the pulmonary vasculature. 
❌ Presence of bruit on carotid auscultation :
Incorrect: This answer describes carotid stenosis, which occurs due to build up of athersclerotic plaque inside the carotid vessels. If a portion of the plaque breaks off, it can cause a stroke. However, this patient’s heart murmur and DVT are more consistent with the presentation of a paradoxical emboli. 
✅ Increased oxygen saturation in the right atrium :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Irregularly irregular rhythm on electrocardiography :
Incorrect: This answer describes atrial fibrillation, a condition which increases the risk of thrombus formation. If a portion of the thrombus breaks off and travels to the brain, it can cause a stroke. However, atrial fibrillation would not present with fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother because she is concerned that he is having frequent episodes of breathing difficulty. His mother reports that these episodes occur especially after running around the house, and he often has to squat down to catch his breath. The patient was born at 38 weeks gestation following an uncomplicated pregnancy, in which the mother received full prenatal care. The patient is at the 35th percentile for length and below the 10th percentile for weight. While being examined, he starts to cry, and cyanosis is noted around the lips. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 87%. Further evaluation will most likely reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Increased blood pressure in the arms
Fixed splitting of S2 on cardiac auscultation
Decreased pulmonary markings on chest radiograph
Double aortic arch on magnetic resonance angiography

questions.solution:
Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a congenital heart defect characterized by 4 key features (remembered with the mnemonic PROVe):  

  1.  Pulmonary infundibular stenosis 
  2.  Right ventricular hypertrophy 
  3.  Overriding aorta 
  4.  Ventricular septal defect (VSD) 
Cyanosis in TOF is due to right-to-left shunting across the VSD that occurs secondary to the increased pressure in the right ventricle from the pulmonary stenosis. Children with TOF experience typical episodes of shortness of breath and cyanosis, also known as “tet spells,” that are precipitated by crying and exercise. During the cyanotic event, children often assume a squatting position in order to increase the systemic vascular resistance, thereby reducing the to right-to-left shunting.  



The right ventricular outlet obstruction leads to decreased development of the lungs, which is seen as decreased pulmonary markings on chest x-ray (CXR). In addition, the obstruction leads to right ventricular hypertrophy, which is classically described on CXR as a “boot-shaped” heart.  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

“Boot shaped” heart and reduced left lung vascular markings in a TOF patient  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased blood pressure in the arms:
Incorrect: Increased blood pressure in both arms is seen with coarctation of the aorta, which is associated with Turner syndrome. “Tet spells” and episodic cyanosis are characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot.   
❌ Fixed splitting of S2 on cardiac auscultation:
Incorrect: Fixed splitting of S2 is usually seen in a patient with an atrial septal defect (ASD) or with right bundle branch block. Patients with Tetralogy of Fallot have a ventricular septal defect, not an ASD.
✅ Decreased pulmonary markings on chest radiograph:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left axis deviation on electrocardiogram:
Incorrect: Left axis deviation is expected with an endocardial cushion defect, which includes the atrial septum, ventricular septum and atrioventricular valves, forming an atrioventricular septal defect. The condition is commonly seen in children with Down syndrome. TOF instead presents with right axis deviation on ECG, due to the hypertrophy of the right ventricle, which results from the right ventricular outlet obstruction.
❌ Double aortic arch on magnetic resonance angiography:
Incorrect: Vascular ring is a condition in which the aorta is split and surrounds both the trachea and esophagus. Symptoms of vascular ring include pulmonary symptoms such as stridor, respiratory distress, wheezing, and cough, as well as esophageal complaints such as dysphagia, feeding difficulties and vomiting. Periodic cyanosis can occur, but these other symptoms would also be expected.

questions.text:
A 2-hour-old male infant is evaluated in the nursery for suspected hearing loss. He was born at 39-weeks gestational age via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient’s mother immigrated to the United States three months ago and had limited access to prenatal care in her home country. The patient is at the 15th percentile for height and weight. Vitals are within normal limits. Auditory brainstem response test shows findings consistent with hearing loss. Examination of the patient’s eyes reveals the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

 Which of the following findings will be most likely present on this patient’s cardiac examination?

choices.text: Machine-like murmur loudest at the left infraclavicular area
Fixed splitting of the S2 heart sound
Systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border with radiation to the right sternal border
Blowing diastolic murmur loudest at the right upper sternal border

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has congenital rubella syndrome, which is characterized by deafness, cataracts, blueberry muffin rash, and a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).    

PDA occurs when the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. This patency leads to a left-to-right shunt, wherein high-pressure blood in the aorta is able to enter the low-pressure pulmonary artery. Other risk factors for developing a PDA include preterm birth and in utero alcohol exposure.    

Clinically, it presents with a continuous machine-like murmur at the left infraclavicular area. In addition, patients can develop differential cyanosis, which is when the lower extremities are cyanotic but the upper extremities are acyanotic. This finding is because the ductus arteriosus originates in the aortic arch distal to where the subclavian arteries branch off. As a result, sufficiently oxygenated blood reaches the upper extremities, but inadequate blood reaches the lower extremities. Cardiac catheterization will reveal increased oxygen saturation in the pulmonary artery.  

Indomethacin, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication, blocks synthesis of prostaglandin E and is used to treat PDA. If this fails, surgical intervention is needed.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Pericardial friction rub :
Incorrect: A pericardial friction rub can be secondary to pericarditis, which is often triggered by a viral illness. However, this patient’s hearing loss and cataracts raise concerns for congenital rubella syndrome. It would be atypical for it to cause pericarditis. 
✅  Machine-like murmur loudest at the left infraclavicular area :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Fixed splitting of the S2 heart sound :
Incorrect: This finding would be heard in a patient with an atrial septal defect (ASD). Alcohol exposure in utero and trisomy 21 are associated with ASD. However, this patient’s physical examination findings of hearing loss and cataracts are more consistent with congenital rubella syndrome, which is associated with a different cardiac finding. 
❌ Systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border with radiation to the right sternal border :
Incorrect: This finding is consistent with the presentation of tricuspid regurgitation. Children exposed to lithium in utero are at risk of developing tricuspid regurgitation and atrialization of the right ventricle (Ebstein anomaly). However, it would be atypical for in utero lithium exposure to cause hearing loss or cataracts, and thus another congenital syndrome is more likely. 
❌ Blowing diastolic murmur loudest at the right upper sternal border :
Incorrect: This answer describes aortic regurgitation. The condition is seen in patients with connective tissue disorders, such as Marfan syndrome. However, this patient’s symptoms of hearing loss and infantile cataracts are more consistent with the presentation of congenital rubella infection.

questions.text:
A 3-day-old female infant is brought to the emergency department due to difficulty breathing. She was born at term through normal vaginal delivery to a 30-year-old woman who had full prenatal care. The mother reports that the patient was fine after birth and recently started developing blue-colored skin and rapid breathing at home. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 80% on room air. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows PO2 of 30 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central cyanosis and retractions of the rib cage. 100% oxygen through a nasal cannula and PGE1 are administered. The patient’s airway is stable, and a chest radiograph is obtained (shown below). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This previously healthy infant who was born to a mother who had prenatal care is now presenting several days after birth with central cyanosis, hypoxemia, and tachypnea, which imply the condition is patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) dependent. Along with the chest x-ray findings showing classic “egg on a string” appearance and increased pulmonary markings, the most likely diagnosis is D-transposition of the great vessels (D-TGA). 

D-TGA is a congenital heart defect in which the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle, resulting in 2 parallel circulations. The condition is not well understood but is thought to occur due to failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral. Due to this parallel circuitry, blood from the right ventricle leaves through the aorta to the body, and then flows back to the right atrium and ventricle (blood never becomes oxygenated). Then, blood from the left ventricle leaves through the pulmonary artery to the lungs, where it flows through to the pulmonary veins, left atrium and left ventricle (the oxygenated blood never gets delivered to the organs).    

The postnatal clinical features are dependent on the degree of mixing between the two circulations and the presence of other cardiac anomalies. For the condition to be compatible with life, a mixing of the blood must be allowed. This can occur if there is a patent foramen ovale, ventricular septal defect, or PDA. The PDA typically closes in the first few days of life, resulting in cyanosis if the congenital heart defect is PDA-dependent, as seen here. Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1), also known as alprostadil, can be administered to help keep the PDA open while waiting for surgery. If left uncorrected, most infants die within the first year of life.  





Option Analysis

❌ Persistent truncus arteriosus:
Incorrect: Persistent truncus arteriosus (TA) is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn in which there is a failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form resulting in a common arterial trunk. Chest radiography in TA typically shows cardiac enlargement and increased pulmonary vascular markings, rather than the “egg on a string” appearance seen in this patient. TA is associated with DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion) and other exam features would be expected. Additionally, TA is not patent ductus arteriosus dependent (See Main Explanation).
✅ D-transposition of the great vessels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tricuspid atresia:
Incorrect: Tricuspid atresia is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn and is characterized by congenital agenesis or absence of the tricuspid valve. On chest radiograph in a newborn with tricuspid atresia, the smooth convexity of the right heart border is absent, and the right heart border does not cross beyond the spine. Additionally, tricuspid atresia results in decreased pulmonary flow, leading to decreased pulmonary markings on chest radiograph, rather than increased, as seen here.
❌ Tetralogy of Fallot:
Incorrect: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is also characterized by early cyanosis. The presentation is variable and depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Chest radiograph in a newborn with TOF will likely show a “boot-shaped” heart and decreased pulmonary markings, unlike here, as the right ventricular outflow obstruction leads to decreased pulmonary flow. Additionally, the condition is characterized by “tet spells,” which are cyanotic episodes triggered by crying, feeding or physical activity, rather than progressive cyanosis. 
❌ Total anomalous pulmonary venous return :
Incorrect: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) is another cause of early cyanosis in which the four pulmonary veins fail to make their normal connection to the left atrium and instead drain into the right atrium. A chest radiograph in a newborn with TAPVR chest radiograph may show a classic “snowman” appearance. Additionally, TAPVR is not patent ductus arteriosus dependent (See Main Explanation).

questions.text: An 11-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a routine visit. The parents have no acute complaints, and the patient has been meeting developmental milestones. Family history is notable for hypertension in her father and an atrial septal defect in her older brother. The rest of the history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for a III/VI harsh, holosystolic murmur most prominent at the left lower sternal border. Pulmonary and abdominal examination is unremarkable. Review of the patient’s medical record reveals that no murmur was heard at the time of birth. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s findings?

choices.text: Impaired growth of the septum primum
Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close
Anterosuperior displacement of the interventricular septum
Incomplete development of the interventricular septum
Incomplete closure of the mitral valve during systole

questions.solution:
This infant with examination finding of harsh, holosystolic murmur most prominent at the left lower sternal border without accompanying symptoms (e.g. cyanosis) most likely has a ventricular septal defect (VSD).  

Ventricular septal defects arise due to impaired development or fusion of the two portions of interventricular septum. One is a membranous portion, which is the upper one-third, and the other is a muscular portion, which is the lower two-thirds. Defects usually occur in the membranous portion. Most VSDs are small and close on their own.    

Individuals with VSDs are asymptomatic at birth but can develop symptoms several weeks later. This delay is because after delivery, there is a gradual decline in pulmonary vascular resistance which results in a decrease in right ventricular pressure. Blood is then able to pass more readily from the left heart through the VSD into the right heart, producing a holosystolic murmur.  

On auscultation, the murmur can be heard at the left lower sternal border. Of note, the smaller the defect, the louder the murmur. This finding is because when blood rushes through a narrower opening, it produces more turbulence and hence more noise. In addition, because the defect allows oxygenated blood to move into the right heart, cardiac catheterization will show increased oxygen saturation in the right ventricle and pulmonary artery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired growth of the septum primum :
Incorrect: This answer describes an atrial septal defect (ASD). ASDs present with a fixed-split S2 sound and a murmur loudest at the left upper sternal border. In contrast, this patient has a harsh, holosystolic murmur that is most prominent at the left lower sternal border. 
❌ Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close :
Incorrect: This answer describes a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which usually presents with a continuous machine-like murmur most prominent at the left infraclavicular area. It would be atypical for PDA to instead cause a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. 
❌ Anterosuperior displacement of the interventricular septum :
Incorrect: This pathology would result in Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). One finding in TOF is a ventricular septal defect with a right-to-left shunt. Patients with TOF can have episodes of cyanosis triggered by crying or exercise. Although this patient’s murmur is consistent with that of a VSD, she lacks the other history and physical examination findings of TOF or a right-to-left shunt.  
✅ Incomplete development of the interventricular septum :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Incomplete closure of the mitral valve during systole :
Incorrect: This pathology results in mitral regurgitation, which causes a systolic murmur loudest over the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line) that radiates to the axilla. In contrast, this patient’s murmur is loudest over the left lower sternal border.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of leg pain that is exacerbated by exercise. The patient reports having difficulty keeping up with her classmates while playing soccer at school. She has not started having menses. Her mother had menarche at the age of 12. The patient’s temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min. Upper extremity blood pressure is 140/81 mmHg, and lower extremity blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a low posterior hairline, Tanner stage I breasts and webbed neck.  Which of the following additional examination findings will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with symptoms of claudication and hypotension in lower extremities most likely has coarctation of aorta (CoA). The history of primary amenorrhea, together with examination findings of  low posterior hairline, Tanner stage I breasts and webbed neck strongly suggest Turner syndrome, which is associated with increased risk of developing CoA.  

CoA can be divided into two types: preductal and postductal. The preductal type occurs when aortic narrowing occurs before the ductus arteriosus. This type causes right-to-left shunting of blood, which usually presents with differential cyanosis between the upper and lower extremities. The postductal type occurs when aortic narrowing occurs after the ductus arteriosus. This type does not cause shunting and thus is acyanotic.  

Both types of CoA can cause upper extremity hypertension. In addition, if too little blood reaches the legs, patients can develop claudication that is exacerbated by exercise. Another finding is rib notching. This finding arises because the anterior intercostal arteries come from the internal thoracic artery, a branch of the right subclavian, and the posterior intercostals come from the descending aorta. This anatomy can thus provide a collateral circulation to bypass the aortic narrowing. However, the problem is these intercostal arteries are now under high pressure, resulting in dilation. These dilated arteries rub up against the ribs, and over time, the ribs can develop notches that are visible on chest x-ray. 

Option Analysis

✅ Rib notching :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thymic aplasia :
Incorrect: DiGeorge syndrome arises from defects in the 3rd and 4th branchial arches. It can cause thymic aplasia. However, the condition is not associated with CoA. 
❌ Upslanting palpebral fissures :
Incorrect: This feature is seen in trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). Cardiovascular anomalies that are associated with trisomy 21 include endocardial cushion defects (e.g., atrial or ventricular septal defect), patent ductus arteriosus and tetralogy of Fallot. However, trisomy 21 is not associated with CoA. 
❌ Pectus carinatum :
Incorrect: This condition is a rare malformation characterized by protrusion of the sternum and ribs. It is associated with connective tissue disorders such as Marfan or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. However, these conditions are not associated with CoA, which is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s leg pain and upper extremity hypertension.  
❌ Smooth hypoplastic philtrum :
Incorrect: A smooth hypoplastic philtrum is seen in fetal alcohol syndrome. The condition can cause cardiac defects ranging from ventricular septal defects to patent ductus arteriosus. However, it is not associated with CoA.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency room for evaluation of left-sided weakness and slurred speech that began three hours ago. She is currently taking oral contraceptives. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She has a 8 pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 71/min and blood pressure is 127/81 mmHg. BMI is 36 kg/m2. Physical examination shows motor strength of ⅗ on the left side. Cardiac exam reveals a systolic murmur loudest at the left upper sternal border and fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound. Extremity examination reveals swelling and erythema in the right calf. MRI of the brain shows signs of an ischemic infarction. Which of the following best explains the finding observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of smoking, obesity and use of oral contraceptive pills is presenting with swelling and erythema in the right calf. These findings are consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Moreover, she most likely has an atrial septal defect (ASD), given the examination finding of a fixed split S2 heart sound. The clot likely travelled to the right atrium and passed through the defect into the arterial circulation, ending up in cerebral vasculature, causing a stroke. This phenomenon is termed paradoxical embolism, which is a known complication of ASD.  

A similar cardiac condition is patent foramen ovale (PFO), which occurs when the septum primum and septum secundum fail to fuse after birth. This can result in transient right-to-left shunting of blood with straining or coughing. However, a PFO would not present with the fixed-split S2 heart sound found in ASD.  

Both conditions can cause paradoxical embolus because instead of going from the right atrium to the right ventricle and to the lungs, the embolus can pass through the defect into the left atrium and, eventually, into the systemic circulation.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Factor V Leiden deficiency :
Incorrect: Factor V Leiden, the most common cause of inherited hypercoagulability, can predispose patients to develop a DVT. However, the fact that an embolus from this patient’s DVT travelled to the brain as opposed to the lungs raises concerns for a paradoxical embolism. An ASD would explain the paradoxical embolism with these cardiac examination findings.  
❌ Patent foramen ovale :
Incorrect: A patent foramen ovale (PFO) can cause a paradoxical embolus. It can cause transient right-to-left shunting of blood during straining or coughing. However, a PFO would not result in the constant left-to-right shunting that is needed to produce a fixed-split S2 heart sound. Hence, an ASD is a more likely explanation.  
❌ Ventricular septal defect :
Incorrect: A ventricular septal defect (VSD) can result in a paradoxical embolus. However, it usually causes a holosystolic murmur loudest at the left lower sternal border with or without a thrill. 
✅ Atrial septal defect :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Carotid artery stenosis :
Incorrect: Carotid artery stenosis is caused by atherosclerotic plaque deposition. If a portion of the plaque breaks off, it can travel to the brain and result in a stroke. However, this patient has a DVT and cardiac murmur, which are more consistent with the presentation of a paradoxical embolus.

questions.text: A 1-day-old female newborn is being evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit for severe respiratory distress and cyanosis. The patient was born at 38 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery to a 30-year-old woman who had minimal prenatal care. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 150/min, blood pressure is 87/55 mm Hg, and respiration rate is 60/min. An electrocardiogram reveals left axis deviation with a superior axis and chest x-ray shows decreased pulmonary markings and a hypoplastic right ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tricuspid valve atresia is a cyanotic congenital heart defect characterized by congenital agenesis or absence of the tricuspid valve which results in the absence of direct communication between the right atrium and ventricle. If left untreated, tricuspid atresia has a high mortality rate, with a survival rate as low as 10% at 1 year of life.  

The chest radiograph in patients with decreased pulmonary flow will often show decreased pulmonary markings due to decreased bloodflow from the right ventricle to the lungs. Cyanotic heart diseases of the newborn can be divided according to the level of pulmonary flow as follows:  

 


The electrocardiogram (ECG) in healthy newborn infants often shows right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy in the first few days of life. Deviation from this physiologic axis can assist in establishing the diagnosis. In patients with tricuspid valve atresia, surface ECG demonstrates tall P waves and left axis deviation with a superior axis (>30°), indicating LV hypertrophy, and diminished RV forces due to a hypoplastic right ventricle. In a cyanotic infant, the above findings are considered pathognomonic for tricuspid valve atresia.  

Initial management includes cardiorespiratory support and medications for stabilization, followed by surgical correction.    

Option Analysis

❌ D-transposition of the great vessels:
Incorrect: The initial electrocardiogram (ECG) in infants with D-transposition of the great vessels (D-TGA) is often normal. In addition, despite having marked hypoxemia, D-TGA pulmonary markings on chest x-ray are normal or increased, rather than decreased. D-TGA often presents with classic chest radiograph features of a heart with an “egg on a string” appearance. 
❌ Persistent truncus arteriosus:
Incorrect: The electrocardiogram findings in patients with persistent truncus arteriosus (TA) are often nonspecific and may be normal. In addition, chest radiograph in TA typically shows cardiac enlargement and increased pulmonary vascular markings. 
❌ Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) :
Incorrect: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR), in which all four pulmonary veins return to the right heart instead of the left side, often presents with non-specific findings on electrocardiogram. The chest radiograph can be normal or may show the classic “snowman” sign. 
❌ Tetralogy of Fallot:
Incorrect: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) also causes decreased pulmonary flow; however, the electrocardiogram in TOF typically shows right axis deviation, prominent R waves anteriorly and S waves posteriorly due right atrial enlargement and right ventricular hypertrophy. This patient has a hypoplastic right ventricle, suggestive of a different condition. 
✅ Tricuspid atresia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is referred to a cardiologist for evaluation for intermittent cyanosis and exercise intolerance. Symptoms began around half-a-year ago, and they have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for a congenital heart defect, which was diagnosed shortly after birth. However, he was subsequently lost to follow-up and was not treated for this condition. The patient smokes half-a-pack of cigarettes per day. Physical exam is notable for cyanosis of the lips and clubbing of the fingers. Cardiac catheterization is performed, and oxygen saturation in the cardiac chambers and outflow tracts are shown below:  

 Which of the following is the most likely explanation of these findings?

choices.text: Impaired growth of the septum primum
Impaired closure of the foramen ovale
Fluid accumulation in the lung parenchyma

questions.solution:
This patient has Eisenmenger syndrome, which is when an uncorrected left-to-right shunt reverses direction and becomes a right-to-left shunt. In this patient’s case, the condition most likely arose secondary to an uncorrected ventricular septal defect, given catheterization finding of decreased saturation in the left ventricle.  

Eisenmenger syndrome occurs as a result of the constant shunting of blood to the right heart, which increases pulmonary blood flow. This high flow state triggers vascular remodeling in the lungs, which is characterized by increased proliferation of vascular smooth muscle and narrowing of pulmonary artery lumen. As a result, the right heart must pump against greater resistance, so it too undergoes remodeling in the form of right ventricular hypertrophy. This growth causes the pressure in the right heart to increase and exceed that of the left heart, ultimately switching the shunt’s direction.    

Clinically, Eisenmenger syndrome presents with cyanosis, hypoxia, and clubbing of the fingers and toes. In addition, patients can develop polycythemia, since hypoxia increases kidney erythropoietin production.  

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired growth of the septum primum :
Incorrect: This pathology would result in an atrial septal defect (ASD). ASDs are a type of left-to-right shunt. Cardiac catheterization will show increased oxygen saturation in the right atrium, ventricle, and pulmonary artery. Even with Eisenmenger syndrome, ASD would lead to decrease in saturation in the left atrium (not the ventricle). 
❌ Impaired closure of the foramen ovale :
Incorrect: A patent foramen ovale (PFO) can cause transient right-to-left shunting of blood. Cardiac catheterization may show reduced oxygen saturation in the left atrium, ventricle, and aorta. In contrast, this patient’s catheterization does not demonstrate this finding. 
✅ Reversal of long-standing left-to-right shunt :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Hyperplasia of bronchial mucus-secreting glands :
Incorrect: This answer describes chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD). COPD can result in a productive cough, barrel chest, cyanosis, and nail clubbing. Patients with a smoking history are at increased risk. Although this patient has a smoking history, he is relatively young and lacks the history of cough characteristic to COPD. 
❌ Fluid accumulation in the lung parenchyma :
Incorrect: This answer describes pulmonary edema. The accumulation of fluids in the lung parenchyma can reduce oxygen exchange and cause cyanosis. However, blood in this patient’s left atrium has high oxygen saturation, suggesting that gas exchange is normal.
